to Argo Workflows i will keep this brief
um there's a much more comprehensive
overview that Becky and my colleague
Darko did um you can follow that QR code
there and go through and watch that talk
so at a high level what is Argo
Workflows um so Argo Workflows
orchestrates workflows in Kubernetes in
other words it's a thing doer it
schedules Kubernetes pods in a specific
order so you can string them together
and just get it to do
something when we define a workflow it
looks a little like the YAML on the left
the important logic is contained within
our workflow spec and we can see it has
a clear structure an entry point and a
list of template definitions
in this example we have a simple
workflow spec with just one step a
single template definition of course we
could have multiple templates listed in
a workflow
spec these template definitions can be
loosely thought of as functions they
define instructions to be
executed the entry point field defines
what the main function will be that is
the template that will be executed
first of course there's much more that
we can do than just this and there are
many different template types to cover
in all there are nine types of template
available in Argo workflows divided into
two different categories there's
template invocators they're used to
invoke or call other templates they
provide execution control for our
workflows and there's template
definitions these as we've mentioned are
what define the work to be done they act
like
functions so let's take a look at our
template
invocators a steps template does exactly
what it says it allows you to define
your tasks in a series of steps these
steps can be run sequentially in
parallel or a combination of
both the way we control the order of
these steps is in the structure of the
template which is set out as a list of
lists normally outer lists will run
sequentially one after another and then
inner lists will run in parallel
so while outer and inner lists give us
some way to control the sequential and
parallel steps there are many more ways
to control the order of execution as you
become more familiar with Argo workflows
so for example you can use a when clause
to conditionally execute steps but if
you're just getting started with
workflows the most important thing to
know is that a steps template allows you
to define a series of steps to
run the other template indicator we can
use is a DAG a DAG template indicator
allows us to define tasks as a graph of
dependencies rather than a list of steps
in other words in a DAG you list all
your tasks and you set which others must
complete before a particular task can
begin tasks with no dependencies will be
run
immediately so in our example here the
gen rand intask will run immediately it
has no dependencies any others however
many that also have no dependencies will
also be run in parallel with it our echo
output and container set tasks both
depend on gen random int so once that
one finishes these next two will be run
in
parallel so our two choices of template
invocators are steps or DAG templates
but which should we use and
when in many cases you can achieve the
same thing using either but there are
some differences between the two and
there are situations where one may be
better suited
steps are simpler they're more readable
for small deterministic workflows but
you'll find them restrictive as they
only really allow for sequential or
parallel execution so use steps for
short deterministic
pipelines dags offer much more
flexibility and control for larger
workflows you can define many
dependencies in a large workflow and
Argo workflows will use all the
information and work out the best
parallelism for your tasks
some people can find the DAG structure
harder to pass in the YAML especially
when first getting started or if the DAG
is not well laid out in that
YAML use a tag when a workflow requires
more
flexibility generally once you have some
familiarity with Argo workflows and when
a workflow has more than a few steps I
would personally recommend you use a DAG
now we've covered our template invocator
so our steps and DAG templates let's
have a look at the options we have for
defining each individual step or task in
our workflow there are seven of these in
total so we'll start with probably the
most familiar the container template
definition exactly as we'd expect the
container template allows us to define a
container that will run as a workflow
step here we've got a very simple hello
world example which Argo workflows will
run inside a pod for us when this runs
the standard output from our step is
collected and saved into something
called the result output parameter which
means we can use that in later steps
this probably looks very familiar the
spec for our template here is the same
as the Kubernetes container spec so you
can define a container here the same way
you would anywhere else in
Kubernetes you can't see it in this
example but it's also possible for us to
use in it and sidecar containers here
too
now just because this is simple doesn't
mean it isn't powerful in many cases
this template type is a great option and
a sensible default choice if in doubt
start with a container template but of
course there are other options available
to us and the first of these looks an
awful lot like what we were just talking
about that's because this option the
script template is really a convenience
wrapper around a container template
you'll notice we've added the source
field which allows us to define a script
in place and this script is saved into a
file and executed for you inside that
container using the command you
specify similar to a container template
the result of the script is
automatically exported into that result
variable so you can use it in later
steps but there is a difference because
the script must be able to run from a
file if the command you specify doesn't
know how to run things from a file use a
container template instead the key
takeaway here is really most of the time
unless you have a strong preference for
a script template you may as well use a
container
template but both of these types do have
some limitations what about if we want
to be able to run multiple containers in
the same pod and we want to control some
dependencies between those containers we
want to order them
this is what the container set template
is designed to help us with it allows us
to run multiple userdefined containers
in a single step so a single pod and to
define the order in which they run we
can see an example here with two
containers but of course we could have
more and because they run in the same
pod they'll be scheduled on the same
host which means they'll have a shared
workspace an empty directory volume use
a container set template when you want
to combine shortlived containers into
one step this is efficient because it
reduces the time and resource overhead
of waiting for multiple init and weight
containers to spin up as we mentioned
because you can set out dependencies you
also have control over
ordering be aware as their name implies
these can only use container templates
within them not script resource etc and
using multiple containers in the same
pod has resource and scheduling implic
imp implications especially if those
containers are larger so we would
recommend looking at the guidance on
understanding and setting resource
requests for these templates in the Argo
workflows docs linked
here this brings us to our next question
which is what if we want to run
something that is not a container well
another option is to act directly on
Kubernetes resources in our workflow
step we do this using the resource
template this template allows us to take
all the typical actions you would expect
to be able to take against Kubernetes
resources get create apply delete
replace or patch commands for example on
the right here we have a resource
template that sets out a config map we
want to create in the cluster what
happens when this actually runs
technically I've been slightly
misleading here because I said no
containers in reality there is still a
container running here it's just we
haven't defined it and we don't normally
need to care about it instead when this
resource template runs workflow
controller actually creates a pod for us
it manages handling that action in this
case creating a config map we'd like to
spend a little bit longer on the
resource template here uh because we
have a few tips we hope will help you
get the most out of them
first of all think about what you want
to happen to these resources at the end
of your workflow do you want resources
created by a resource template to be
cleaned up when your workflow ends if
you don't you don't need to do anything
but if you do you can use the set owner
reference field to enable this you can
also set success condition and failure
condition so your workflow step knows
whether or not the resource ran or
deployed successfully and if you would
like to be able to get pod logs from the
resource template into your workflow
logs there is a magic label for that we
label the pod with the workflow name so
that this can be picked up and then you
can see those logs in the
UI of course whilst we are talking about
resources it's worth mentioning that a
workflow itself is a type of Kubernetes
resource this means you can use a
resource template to create more
workflows this is commonly known as the
workflow of workflows pattern you can
find examples and discussion of this in
the
docs but remember when defining a
resource template Kubernetes arback
still applies if you want to perform an
action on a resource make sure the
service account you're using has peri
permission to perform that action and
for all these cases where you are doing
something to a resource you could
actually do all of these things inside a
pod running cubectl command in other
words you could do these things in a
container template why does this matter
well if we're acting on or changing one
or two resources then a resource
template just makes sense argo workflows
handles a bunch of stuff for us however
if you need to run multiple commands
lots of actions on many resources that
means lots of resource templates and
more importantly lots of
pods so depending on what you want to do
how much visibility you want Argo
workflows to have over this what you'd
like to be able to see in the UI and how
much resource efficiency matters in your
scenario sometimes a resource template
makes complete sense and is the right
choice but if you're thinking purely
about efficiency and you want to perform
many actions this might be more
efficient inside a container
template one thing that does not happen
inside its own container is the suspend
templates we use these when we want to
pause or suspend workflow execution
either for a given duration like the 20
seconds here or until it is resumed
manually we can resume either from the
CLI the UI or the API
endpoint when this template is used it
doesn't use cluster resources instead
when our delay step here is active that
suspension suspension is handled within
workflow controller itself this is one
of the very few times where a step or
task in Argo workflows is not equivalent
to a pod running in Kubernetes
that feels like a good time for us to
state take a step back and look at what
we have covered so far the container
template which runs our defined
container inside a pod the script
template our convenience wrapper around
a container template that runs a script
the container set for running multiple
containers within the same pod with some
dependencies defined we spent a bit of
time discussing the resource template
which allows us to perform actions
directly on Kubernetes resources and of
course the suspend template which allows
us to suspend workflow
execution five covered two more to go
and we've left some interesting ones
till last these two have some
commonalities it's worth us digging into
the HTTP and plug-in templates both run
in a special pod the agent pod which
Argo manages for us if we use multiple
instances of these template types within
the same workflow Argo will reuse this
one pod for those subsequent steps this
saves time on pod startup and uses
cluster resources efficiently however it
does mean we need to add some extra
permissions which we've linked to here
and it abstracts some logic away which
may make it a little bit harder for us
to reason
about the HTTP template is useful when
we want to communicate out to
third-party systems this template type
allows us to execute HTTP requests and
capture the response the body of the
request is automatically exported into
that result variable that we mentioned
earlier and that means again we can use
it in later steps in this example we are
making a very simple get request but we
could use any standard request method
here this template gives us many options
to configure our request and again we
can use success and failure conditions
to determine whether a step should be
marked as failed or successful you can
find a more detailed walkthrough of this
template type in the video that we've
linked in the
slides our final template type is the
plug-in and there are actually two
important concepts here the plug-in
template which we see on the left and
something called an executive plug-in a
plug-in template runs or references an
executive plugin that's something that
we need to have defined beforehand and
then the plug-in template allows us to
use that in a workflow step or
task executive plugins were introduced
to allow users to extend our Go
workflows without needing to learn the
codebase or contribute directly to it
these can be written in any language so
you don't have to use Go if you don't
want to and they run as a containerized
application that uh responds to RPC HTTP
requests a few things to note executive
plugins are not enabled by
default and if considering plugins our
advice is use with caution and the
reason we're saying this is because if
you're using them as a they're not
really intended as a library or shared
bank of vetted plugins you'll need to
vet them yourself if you want use ones
that have already been written they're
more for specific customer needs custom
needs that aren't met by any other
template type in other words use them
where they make sense but avoid
reinventing the wheel is there another
existing template type that makes sense
here uh perfect time to remind ourselves
of those other template types and one of
the aims of this talk is to try and make
your life your use of templates in Argo
workflows easier the easiest rule here
is consider if there is a template type
that clearly meets your needs if there
is use that one
if not start by trying to use a
container template that's because these
are easy to reason about and under your
control another way to make things
easier is to set sensible defaults in
particular here we are talking about
template defaults you can set these in
workflow controller config map that's
your global or Argo workflows wide
defaults at the workflow level or you
can override these in individual
templates where the defaults don't
